summary: This document is a collection of administrative records from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York related to the incarceration of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes a memorandum about file removal, prisoner intake forms, an arrest warrant, a custody alert notice, a property record, and security data. The records show Epstein was in custody on federal sex trafficking charges at the time of his death. This document is a collection of administrative forms and records from the Federal Bureau of Prisons and U.S. Marshals Service related to the intake and custody of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York in July 2019. It includes inmate discipline data, personal property records, prisoner remand forms, an inmate profile, a medical records release form, an arrest warrant, and a custody alert notice. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, including his personal property inventory, intake forms, and administrative records from his incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York in July 2019. It details the items he possessed upon intake and his inmate status information. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons intake forms for Jeffrey Epstein upon his arrival at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York on July 8, 2019. It includes his acknowledgment of prison policies on mail, funds, telephone monitoring, and safety regulations, as well as an intake screening and interview form.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was a federal prisoner (register number 76318-054) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.
He was arrested and charged with sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors under Title 18, U.S. Code.
An administrative memo dated August 13, 2019, notes that an 'Associate' removed Epstein's original prison file, and copies were made for a duplicate file.
Prison records list his custody alerts, including 'Sex Offense Alerts' and 'Mental Concerns / Suicidal Tendencies'.
The arrest warrant was issued by U.S. Magistrate Judge Barbara Moses on July 2, 2019, in the Southern District of New York.
Jeffrey Epstein was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York (MCC NYM) under register number 76318-054.
The specific charges listed are sex trafficking conspiracy (18 U.S.C. § 371) and sex trafficking of minors (18 U.S.C. §§ 1591(a), (b)(2), and (2)).
An arrest warrant was issued by Magistrate Judge Barbara Moses on July 2, 2019, in the Southern District of New York.
Epstein's inmate profile indicates he was housed in 'HOUSE 2/RANGE 04/BED 206L AD' and was categorized as 'CARE1-MENTAL HEALTH'.
A 'Prisoner Custody Alert Notice' includes an alert for 'Mental Concerns / Suicide Threat', indicating special monitoring was in place.
Jeffrey Epstein was incarcerated under register number 76318-054 at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC New York).
The charges listed against him are 'Sex Trafficking Conspiracy' and 'Sex Trafficking of Minors'.
An inmate personal property record dated July 8, 2019, details the items in his possession upon intake, including clothing, food, toiletries, and reading materials.
A visitor list query for Epstein returned 'NO DATA' as of July 22, 2019.
The document includes standard FBI fingerprint and identification forms (FD-249) for Epstein, noting his arrest date and charges.
Jeffrey Epstein was processed into the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York on July 8, 2019, as inmate register number 76318-054.

During intake screening, Epstein answered 'NO' to questions about whether he should not be placed in general population, if he had assisted law enforcement, if he was a member of a gang, and if he had ever been sexually assaulted.

The forms indicate Epstein was a pretrial inmate and was informed of Bureau of Prisons policies regarding mail monitoring, management of inmate funds, telephone call recording, and safety regulations.
Epstein signed a form certifying receipt of an inmate ID card/lanyard from MCC New York staff, acknowledging it must be kept visible and would be confiscated for court appearances.
